original_comment:
1. I noticed that out of all of the countries, there were only 3 countries whose adults over 40 years old believe that the world is getting better. But even then, only 45-60% of adults in these countries actually believe this. 

Indonesia is the only country where over 75% of its population of 15-24 year olds things the world is getting better. The rest of the countries' percentage of believers range from anywhere between 25%-75%. 

2. I wonder how human development influenced these results. Around 15-24 years of age, you slowly but surely start to lose your innocence as more terrible aspects of the world become clear. That may be why so few people in that age range actually believe that the world can experience a positive change. original_comment: What I find both interesting and predictable is that in most countries, there are more 15-24-year-olds than 40+-year-olds who think that the world is getting better with each generation. It took me a second to recognize, but the countries on the top left side of the line (positive residual) have higher percentages of younger adults than older adults who believe that the world is getting better, while on the bottom right (negative residual) show that the older adults think that the world is getting better more than, the younger adults. It makes sense that older people wouldn't believe that the world is improving since there are more progressive young adults and conservative older adults. This leads me to wonder, how would these statistics change as time continues to progress and younger adults become older adults? Since new concepts are built each generation, it makes sense that those older than the latest generation would have a hard time understanding how the world is changing and thus not want it to change. This is important to remember to ensure that the world truly continues to get better and that all generations can be excited and confident about those changes.

original_comment:
The most evident feature of this graph is that the amount of people aged 15-24 believe that the world gets better with each generation is very large, compared to the other portion of the graph, describing 40+ year olds. The second thing that I noticed was that the countries inside of the 40+ boundary are not in Europe or the Americas, but in Africa and Asia. Does that show that middle aged adults are more confident in their successors compared to the west? Another thing that I noticed is that the younger generations feel much better about themselves versus the older generations. The disconnect between young people and older people about the future is more alarming than anything else.

The biggest thing that I wonder is how the younger generation is so optimistic, given that many of their key development years have been distorted due to the pandemic. Adults have had the privilege to go through decades of their lives without worrying the virus, so naturally shouldn't they be more hopeful that things would go back to normal?

This affects me and my community because my life has been effected because of growing up in the pandemic. As a member of the 15-24 year old group, I can say that we've been able to find hope and happiness despite all of the negative things that have been happening in the world. I think it's important for the older generations to find some too.

original_comment: This scatter plot, representing the data between two discrete variables with moderate positive correlation, shows how young adults (ages 15-24 years old) are more optimistic than 40+ years old adults. The audience can be psychologists, therapists, counselors, or anyone concerned about mental health, directing them towards pessimistic adults and offering help. The meaning of this plot can mean the world is becoming a better place because present young adults didn’t have to experience as much pain or suffering the 40+ years old adults did when they were younger. Another takeaway could be that older people have learned the negativity in our world through life experiences; hence, they are less optimistic. For instance, young adults could have big or unrealistic dreams and hopes for their future career, lifestyle, income, etc. But as they age, realizing the realities of how the real world works, it's easy to see why the older adults are less optimistic. The purpose of this plot is to compare and contrast how two different groups of people view our world, providing data for anyone interested.

This graph would help us and geographers understand some people's views, which could lead to further research into why the younger generations have a positive prospect on their generation. It's indisputable that for even the most pessimistic country, Mali, the younger generation of the sample agrees that the world is improving. Why would the younger generations be so optimistic, why would the older generation be so pessimistic? There are many plausible reasons for this, firstly, the younger generation is born into a relatively more privileged and peaceful era, the worst a gen z could go through is the SARS or COVID-19 epidemics. I would say that most gen z's aren't hit by reality yet, the capacity for a gen z to think broad and critically is inferior to a gen x, the youth has baseless ambitions for future success, or rather, hasn't been hit by reality yet. Gen x is more pessimistic as they have most likely been hit with life and given up on some, they do not have the important resource - youth, health - that gen z has. This graph does show good news, improvement of any scale requires people with ambitions, and this graph ensures us that gen z's have the confidence of creating a better world.

The survey was fairly distributed (based on diversity) in these aspirations of generations bettering the world as time progresses. I have also noticed the lack of 40+ year-old participants, which I perceive as a sign that their opinion is rather less significant in this topic, because their generation has fundamentally passed. I believe that 15–24-year old’s are more reliable in this survey, because they are the current generation and could be considered as people who still have time to take new steps to better the world. Due to this, this graph in my perspective is unreliable, these countries are in completely different circumstances (whether it’s in terms of GDP, environment, health, safety etc.). Therefore, ‘better’ is complete bias. Different standards are incompatible. Coming from myself, a citizen of the poorest country in the world, Burundi, my standards of ‘better’, definitely can’t be similar to the standards of someone from one of the richest countries in the world (USA). original_comment:
Ignorance is Bliss?

 **What do you notice?**

I notice that in general, young people, aged 15-24 are more optimistic about the future than older people aged over 40. In developed countries of greater wealth, the divide between the youth and over 40s is more significant compared to the difference in less wealthy countries. Surprisingly, the quality of life in the countries doesn’t seem to have a clear relationship with the optimism of its people, with several countries that have a large percentage of its people in poverty or in conflict ranking higher than that of the USA, Germany, Japan and France. 

- **What do you wonder?**

I wonder why Indonesian youth adults are so positive about the future in comparison to other countries and whether this has to do with their quality of life, culture and government system. I also wonder what causes people, in general, to become less hopeful for the future when they are older, and whether the hopes of young people are misplaced and a result of naive idealism and the belief that they have the power to change the future for the better. Is it because older people have less faith in the younger generations that they believe that things will get worse?

original_comment: [4/5] I wonder if the poll is deemed adequately convincing since the 1,000 respondents on average from each country represent only a tiny portion of the countries’ total population. One thousand people out of the U.K.’s 67 million people is a mere 0.0015%, which cannot precisely tell what the people of the U.K. generally think about this question. In addition, these interviews are not done in person or through video chats, but through telephone calls, which means that respondents don't have to take it seriously. This further takes away the credibility of the polls. While we could argue that covering 1,000 respondents from every country is still a pretty large sample size since it’s not possible to cover everybody or interview everybody in person, we should still leave our doubts on the credibility of the polls. In addition, the poll was asking respondents to address what they think regarding the entire world, but most people might only think about their own country, because that’s what matters most to them and that’s what they care about, but what they think about their own countries do not necessarily have a relationship with whether or not the world is getting better. This potential loophole could also adulterate the authenticity and relevance of the survey results regarding the question. But despite all these accounts, this was still an interesting survey that is worthy of noting and further researching.

original_comment: [3/5] The second thing I noticed is that there isn’t a clear cause-and-effect relationship between a country’s status quo and the percentage of people in that country who think the world is getting better. original_comment:
Title: Boomers are a Downer!

This graph shows that, at a global level, young people are more optimistic about the world than older people.  There are a few places where - by a narrow margin - older people are more positive, but it is more common for young people to be substantially more optimistic.  Japan and the US stand out as having round about a 40% gap between proportions of young and old saying the world is getting better.  This is an interesting counterpoint to many discourses around generational attitudes: especially the notion that GenZ is somehow more 'cynical', and also the evidence that the younger generation has a much worse time than the baby boomers when it comes to job security and home ownership prospects.

original_comment:
The first thing I noticed is how 'Young' people tend to lean towards the idea of "the world is getting better with each generation"  more than 'older' people. As in the graph, you can see that most of the 15 - 24-year-olds in the provided countries fall between the 50-75% range, with none under 25%. However, when looking at the Y-axis for people over the age of 40, most countries fall below 50%, and have a significant amount under 25%. 

There is not exactly a noticeable trend among the data, however you do notice that most of the '1st world' countries have a much higher 'optimistic' younger population than an older one. As you can see in the graph, the US, UK, Japan and Germany are all within the 50-75% range on the X-axis (younger people believing the world is getting better), meanwhile on the Y-axis (Older people believing that the world is getting better) all the previously mentioned countries fall below the 50% mark. 

There is an anomaly within this result, which would be Indonesia, as both the younger and older generations agree that the world is getting better as time goes on. This is likely due to the fact that Indonesia's economy has increased by over 600% since the year 2000, this would obviously see a great increase in the quality of life and general welfare of the populace. Under such conditions, it is quite understandable why Indonesia's population generally have such 'high hopes' for the future.

On the contrary, more developed nations such as France and Spain have far higher levels of pessimism, especially amongst the older generations. group.  

I wonder why countries such as Japan have such high levels of pessimism amongst their older generations as opposed to their younger foes. I’m also very curious about why Indonesia is such an outlier in the graph. The country is not fully developed compared to its American and European counterparts.  Also, why does the graph omit 25 to 39-year-olds?

This graph relates to me and my community because we, Americans, are listed on the graph as the US. I’m part of the younger generation meaning that statistically, we are more optimistic than other first-world countries such as Germany, Japan, and Spain.

This graph is showing the levels of optimism amongst both younger and older generations. A younger audience is denoted by someone who is from 15 to 24 years old while the older audience is denoted by someone who is older than 40 years of age. The positive line of 1 shows equal thinking of both age groups. As a country gets further and further from the line, there is a larger disparity between the thinking of younger generations vs older ones. A catchy title would be “The surprising reality of optimism around the world.”

Graph Name: "The generational views on the future of our planet"

We notice how the 15 to 24-year-old age range upholds more optimism in society and views the progress in the world in a more positive way. The slim percentage of people 40+ who view the world in an optimistic way were most commonly from African countries with a slim percentage coming from India. We wonder why the younger age group is more optimistic than the older age group and how the development of each country voting may/may not play an impact on how they view the world as well. As students who all fall into the 15-24 age range, it’s interesting to see how people like us view the world. It’s impactful to see that there is hope and optimism in our generation and in the future generations to come, even through all of the hardships the world is currently facing.

original_comment:
Thanks to all the students who responded. Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received: "The Opposing Futures in the Eyes of Different Generations" by Helena of Pewaukee High School and “The Ages of Optimism” by Zoe, both from Wisconsin, "Generation Battle: Is the World Getting Better or Worse?" by Taim of Gladeville Middle School in Mt. Juliet, Tennessee. 

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back by Friday, Feb. 11 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and a few Stat Nuggets.

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).

View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex). 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, who sees hope in the optimism of our students, and Dashiell Young-Saver of San Antonio, who's become more optimistic about the world after seeing young people's optimism about the world.

numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph shows an upward trend.
2. People who are 15-24 years old tend to be more optimistic than people who are older than 40 years.
3. There is no strong correlation between the development level of a country and the positivity of the country.
4. Some developed countries are quite pessimistic.
5. Some developing countries are very optimistic.
original_comment: there is an upward trend in the graph. It seems that 15-24 year olds tend to be more optimistic than 40+ year olds. Additionally, there is not a strong correlation between how developed a country is and their positivity; some developed countries are quite pessimistic, and some developing countries are very optimistic.

original_comment:
This graph shows how different generations and age groups view the future of world. The younger generation (ages 15-24) are more optimistic about the future of world and believe that the world is getting better with each generation. I noticed that in Indonesia both young adults and older adults are optimistic for the future of the world. I wonder what caused the older generations to lose their faith for the future in the world. I also wonder if the younger adults are biased since they are considered to be the future of the world. This affects my community because I am in the younger generation. I think the future of the world will be bright.
Name for Graph: "Age VS Optimism"
